The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or subsections, nor as any part of the section or subsection, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections or subsections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 32/414 (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect. Sec. 1-5. - Severability. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the governing body that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect the remaining clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to the passage of the ordinances originally included herein, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and added hereto. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ;#rule; of the Code of Ordinances, City of Grovetown, Georgia is hereby amended to read as follows: ____________." The new provision may then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not theretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Grovetown, Georgia is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ;#rule;, which said section (or article or chapter) reads as follows: ____________." The new section (or article or chapter) may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters, or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. Sec. 1-7. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. Charter amendments may be included in like manner. (b) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 33/414 In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ;#rule; through ;#rule;" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations; abatement of nuisances. (a) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city amending this Code, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance or resolution shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6) months or both, or by fine, imprisonment or alternative sentencing as provided by law. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) In addition to the penalties provided in this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the city, as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. (Ord. of 11-25-02) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 34/414 Charter reference— Jurisdiction of municipal court, § 9; providing court costs, § 34; appearance bond, § 16; certiorari, § 17. State law reference— By virtue of the 1983 Const., Art. VI, § 10, ¶ 1, and O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1, the court is now entitled "municipal court;" appointment of judge, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2; maximum punishment authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); powers of judges of municipal courts in criminal cases, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-3; jurisdiction of courts extended, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-22; waiver of jury trial necessary, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-23. Sec. 1-9. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are substantially the same as ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code, ordinance or other public document. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, mutilate, or in any other manner alter any ordinance book or minute book, or any notice posted by the city for the benefit of the public, or any other document or record of the municipal government of the city. Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any rates, fees or charges consistent with this Code; (2) Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; (3) Any ordinance consistent with this Code prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; (4) Any ordinance consistent with this Code fixing salaries of officials, officers or employees of the city; (5) Any budget ordinance or appropriation ordinance; any ordinance levying any tax; (6) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 35/414 Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution to any person; (7) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city; (8) Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; (10) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or providing regulations for platting or subdividing of property; (11) Any ordinance establishing or changing the boundary of the city; (12) Any ordinance regulating zoning in the city; (13) Any ordinance enacted after October 23, 1989. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (2) Charter reference— Municipal court, §§ 9, 34. (2) Cross reference— Personnel, Ch. 12. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 2-1. - Municipal court. There is hereby created in the city a municipal court to be presided over by a judge, appointed as provided in section 9 of the charter. (Ord. No. 1, § 1, 1-12-60) Charter reference— Costs, subpoenas, etc., § 34. State law reference— By virtue of the 1983 Const., Art. VI, § 10, ¶ 1 and O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1, the court is now entitled "municipal court;" appointment of judge, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2; maximum punishment authorized, 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 36/414 O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); powers of judges of municipal courts in criminal cases, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-32-5 et seq., 40-13-22, 40-13-23. Sec. 2-2. - Councilmembers' salary. (a) The mayor shall receive a salary of five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00) per month (six thousand six hundred dollars ($6,600.00) per annum); (b) Each member of the council shall receive three hundred dollars ($300.00) per month (three thousand six hundred dollars ($3,600.00) per annum). (Ord. of 10-24-88, § 1; Ord. No. 105, §§ 1, 2, 4-12-93) Charter reference— Minimum salaries, § 8. Secs. 2-3—2-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL MEETINGS FOOTNOTE(S): (3) Charter reference— Quorum, voting by mayor, passage of measures, § 7; duties of clerk, § 12. Sec. 2-20. - Place. The city council shall hold both regular and special meetings in the appropriate section of the building now known as City of Grovetown City Hall - Community Building. Sec. 2-21. - Order of business. At each regular meeting of the council the following regular order of business shall be observed unless dispensed with by a majority vote of the members present: (1) Call to order by the presiding officer. (2) Reading of minutes of the previous meeting by the city clerk for correction and approval. (3) Grievances from citizens. (4) Communications from the mayor. (5) Reports from committees, the mayor, members of the council and other offices. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 37/414 (6) Old business. (7) New business. (8) Adjournment. Sec. 2-22. - General rules of order. Except as otherwise provided in the charter or this Code, the rules of order and parliamentary procedure contained in "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised," shall govern the transaction of business by and before the council at its meetings. Sec. 2-23. - Disturbing meetings. It shall be unlawful to engage in disorderly or contemptuous behavior which disturbs any meeting of the council. Sec. 2-24. - Legislation—General procedure. The enactment of city legislation shall be accomplished under the provisions of section 7 and other applicable sections of the charter. Sec. 2-25. - Same—Official copy. A true copy of an ordinance which has been duly enacted by the council, signed by the mayor, and attested to by the city clerk, shall be known as an official copy of an ordinance of the city. Secs. 2-26—2-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CODE OF ETHICS Sec. 2-51. - Intent. It is essential to the proper administration and operation of the city that the members of its governing authority be, and give the appearance of being, independent and impartial; that public office not be used for private gain; and that there be public confidence in the integrity of the governing authority. The governing authority finds that the public interest requires that they protect against such conflicts of interest by establishing appropriate ethical standards with respect to the conduct of the members of the governing authority in situations where a conflict may exist. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-52. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term: (1) Complaint means a written sworn statement filed with the mayor or mayor pro tem containing specific allegations of misconduct by a member; provided, however, such allegations must be filed within six (6) months of discovery of the alleged misconduct. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 38/414 (2) Interest means any direct pecuniary benefit, which is not a remote interest held by or accruing to a member of the governing authority as a result of a contract or transaction that is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or with the city. A member of the governing authority shall be deemed to have an interest in transactions involving: a. Any person in the member's immediate family; b. Any person with whom a contractual relationship exists whereby the member may receive any payment or other benefits unless the member is receiving a benefit for goods or services in the normal course of business for which the member has paid a commercially reasonable rate; c. Any business in which the member is a director, officer, employee, agent, or shareholder, except as otherwise provided herein; or d. Any person of whom the member is a creditor, whether secured or unsecured. (3) Governing authority or "member of the governing authority" means the mayor or any council member of the city and any member appointed to any board or commission of the city. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-53. - Prohibitions. No member of the governing authority shall: (1) By conduct give reasonable basis for the impression that any person can improperly influence him/her or unduly enjoy his/her favor in the performance of official acts; (2) Directly or indirectly request, exact, receive, or agree to receive a gift, loan, favor, promise, or thing of value for him/herself or another person if it could reasonably be considered to influence the member in the discharge of official duties; (3) Disclose or otherwise use confidential information acquired by virtue of his/her official position for his/her or another person's private gain; (4) Use his/her official position to attempt to secure privileges that are not available to the general public; 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 39/414 (5) Engage in, accept employment with, or render services for any private business or professional activity when such employment or rendering of services is adverse to and incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties; (6) Engage in any activity or transaction that is prohibited by law now existing or hereafter enacted which is applicable to him/her by virtue of being a member of the governing authority; (7) Use his/her position to request or require an employee to: a. Do clerical work on behalf of the member's family, business, social, church or fraternal interest when such work is not furthering a city interest; b. Perform any work outside the employee's normal course of municipal employment; c. Purchase goods or services to be used for personal, business, or political purposes; and d. Work for the member personally without paying the employee just compensation; (8) Use government property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he/she direct employees to use such property for any purposes other than those officially approved; (9) Use his/her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to himself/herself or persons having an interest. Prohibition (2) of this section shall not apply in the case of; (1) An occasional non-pecuniary gift of insignificant value; (2) An award publicly presented in recognition of public service; (3) A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of the state to engage in the making of such a loan or financial transaction; 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 40/414 (4) Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with Georgia law. Prohibition (5) of this section shall not apply to a member of the governing authority who is a licensed professional and appears on behalf of any applicant in such professional capacity so long as disclosures required by section 2-54 are made to the board or commission chairperson thirty (30) days prior to any action being taken, and the member is associated with the project at the time the initial application is filed. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-54. - Disclosure of conflicts of interest. An appointed member of the governing authority who has an interest that he/she has reason to believe may be affected by his/her official acts or actions or by the official acts or actions of the governing authority shall disclose the precise nature of such interest by written or verbal statement thirty (30) days prior to the governing authority's taking official action on a matter affecting such interest and abstain from discussion and voting. An elected member of the governing authority shall disclose the nature of any interest he/she has at the time such matter is presented to mayor and council for discussion. Such written or verbal statements shall be recorded into the minutes of the meeting and thus become part of the public record. Following any disclosure made pursuant to this section, the member shall refrain from all ex-parte communications with other members regarding the application in which he/she has an interest. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-55. - Disqualification. A member of the governing authority shall disqualify himself/herself from participating in any official act or action of the city which results in a pecuniary benefit to the member or a business or activity in which he/she has an interest, when such benefit is not available to the public at large. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-56. - Prohibited contracts. The city shall not enter into any contract involving services or property with a member of the governing authority or with a business in which a member of the governing authority has an interest. This section shall not apply in the case of: (1) The designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds; (2) The borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan; (3) Contracts entered into in accordance with the O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6; (4) Contracts entered into under circumstances that constitute an emergency situation, provided that the mayor prepares a written record explaining the emergency; 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 41/414 (5) Contracts entered into with a member of the governing authority, or with a business in which a member of the governing authority has an interest, provided that such contract is the result of a competitive bid, disclosure of the nature of such member's interest is made prior to the time any bid is submitted, and a waiver of the prohibition contemplated by this section is issued by the city administrator following disclosure. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-57. - Restrictions on contracts with former members of the governing authority. The city shall not enter into any contract with any person or business represented by such person, who has been within the preceding twelve-month period a member of the governing authority, unless the contract is awarded by a competitive bid or a committee selection process. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-58. - Complaints. Any person having a complaint against any member of the governing authority for an alleged ethics violation shall file in writing a verified complaint setting forth the particular facts and circumstances which constitute the alleged violation against the governing authority. The complaint shall be filed with the mayor, or in the event the complaint regards the mayor, shall be filed with the mayor pro tem. Upon receipt of a complaint, the mayor, or in the event the complaint regards the mayor, the mayor pro tem shall, appoint three (3) members of council, who, along with the city attorney, shall constitute an investigating committee to determine whether the complaint sets forth significant facts and circumstances so as to warrant a hearing before the board of ethics. In the event the complaint does not set forth sufficient facts to constitute an alleged violation and is found unjustified, frivolous or patently unfounded, it shall be dismissed and the complainant notified immediately. In the event the complaint is found to state sufficient facts to warrant a hearing before the board of ethics, the board shall be appointed as provided herein. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-59. - Board of ethics. (a) Composition of the board of ethics: (1) The board of ethics of the city shall be composed of five (5) residents of the city to be appointed as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection. Each member of the board of ethics shall have been a resident of the city for at least one (1) year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has, or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract, transaction, or official action of the city. (2) The mayor and council members shall each designate two (2) qualified citizens to provide a pool of ten (10) individuals who have consented to serve as a member of such board of ethics and who will be available for a period of two (2) years to be called upon to serve in the event a board of ethics is appointed. (3) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 42/414 The city administrator shall maintain a listing of these ten (10) qualified citizens. Should the investigating committee determine a complaint warrants a hearing before the board of ethics, the mayor and council, at the first public meeting after such determination, shall draw names randomly from the listing of qualified citizens until the specified five (5) members of the board of ethics have been appointed. Such board will elect one (1) of its members to serve as chairman. (4) The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation. The governing authority of the city shall provide meeting space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city, the city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for it to perform its duties and responsibilities. (b) The constituted board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers: (1) To establish procedures, rules and regulations governing its internal organization and conduct of its affairs; (2) To hold a hearing within sixty (60) days after the receipt of complaint. Failure to hold a hearing within the specified time shall result in dismissal of the complaint as to the transaction and shall prevent refiling if a complaint arises in the same incident for at least a period of six (6) months; (3) To prescribe forms, approved by the city attorney, for the disclosure required in this article and to make available to the public information disclosed as provided in this section; (4) To receive and hear complaints of violations of the standards required by this article; (5) To make such investigation and response to a complaint as it deems necessary to determine whether any person has violated any provisions of this article; (6) To hold such hearings and make such inquiries as deemed necessary to investigate and rule upon complaints; (7) To report its findings to the governing authority for such action as the governing authority deems appropriate. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-60. - Service of complaint; hearings and disposition of complaints. The board of ethics as appointed herein set forth shall cause the complaint to be served on the member of the governing authority charged as soon as practicable. Service may be by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. A hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days after filing of the complaint. The board of 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 43/414 ethics shall conduct the hearing in accordance with the procedures and regulations it establishes but, in all circumstances, the hearing shall include the taking of testimony and the cross-examination of witnesses. The decision of the board of ethics shall be rendered to mayor and council within five (5) days after completion of the hearing. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-61. - Penalty and member rights. (a) Any member of the governing authority who knowingly violates any provision of the code of ethics provided in this article shall be subject to public reprimand or censure by the governing authority of the city. (b) At any hearing held by the board of ethics, the member of the governing authority who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the allegations at least ten (10) business days before a hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses and to present evidence and witnesses in opposition or in extenuation. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00) Sec. 2-62. - Appeals. (a) Any member of the governing authority or the complainant adversely affected by these findings of the board of ethics may obtain judicial review of such decision as provided in this section. (b) An action for judicial review may be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the superior court of the county within thirty (30) days after the decision of the board of ethics. The filing of such application shall act as supersedes. (Ord. No. 137, 2-28-00)

div.head: Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (4) Editor's note— Ord. No. 147, adopted Nov. 11, 2002, repealed chapter 3, sections 3-1—3-37, 3-40—3-44, and replaced it with a new chapter 3, sections 3-101—3-112, 3-146—3-163, 3-214, 3-216, 3-217, 3-251—3-256. Former chapter 3 pertained to similar material and derived from Ord. No. 55, §§ 1—8, 10—34, 36—47, adopted Aug. 3, 1976; and Ord. of Dec. 23, 1985. (4) Cross reference— Consumption on public property, § 11-1; public drunkenness, § 11-2. (4) State Law reference— Local licensing authority, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; local regulatory authority, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-49, 3-5-40 et seq., 3-6-40. ARTICLE I. - RESERVED Secs. 3-1—3-100. - Reserved. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 44/414 ARTICLE II. - IN GENERAL Sec. 3-101. - Sale of alcoholic beverages in the city; license a privilege. (a) Alcoholic beverages may be sold in the city under a license granted by the city council upon the terms and conditions provided in this chapter. (b) All licenses issued under the terms of this chapter shall be a grant of privilege to carry on the business of selling alcoholic beverages during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by the terms of the license and the ordinances and laws of the city and the state. (c) All licenses issued under the terms of this chapter shall have printed on the front of such licenses the following words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be revoked and annulled, and is subject to any further ordinances which may be enacted by the city council of Grovetown, Georgia." (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-102. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all drinks or beverages containing alcohol, including, but not limited to, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine. Alcoholic treatment facility means any alcohol treatment facility owned and operated by the state, city, or county, including the buildings and the surrounding property or campus directly incorporated into such use. Beer or malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six (6) percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer and strong beer. The terms do not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Church building means the main structure used by any religious organization for purposes of worship and the surrounding property or campus directly incorporated into such use in compliance with the zoning ordinances of the city. A church must have its property zoned as church property prior to asserting any rights as a church with respect to this chapter. City council means the city council board of Grovetown, Georgia. City park or playground means a park, recreation center, ball fields or playgrounds owned and operated by the city for use by the citizens of the city. Distilled spirits or spirituous liquor means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than twenty-one (21) percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 45/414 Eating establishment means a business establishment open to the public which sells prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises, with a full service kitchen which must contain at least a threecompartment pot sink, a commercial grade stove or grill and oven which is permanently installed, and a commercial grade cooler or refrigerator, offering food service every hour such establishment is open, and deriving at least sixty (60) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared food items which shall not include the sale of any alcoholic beverages. An eating establishment which was in operation on January 1, 2003, possessed a city business license at that time, and has been in continuous operation since January 1, 2003, must have its full service kitchen approved by the health department and the engineering department. Any other eating establishment must have its full service kitchen approved by the health department, engineering department and the fire marshal where state law requires the establishment to be inspected by the fire marshal. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage made from fruits, berries or grapes, containing more than twentyone (21) percent alcohol by volume, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, brandy. Governing authority means the city council of Grovetown, Georgia. Hotel means a business establishment open to the public, which provides sleeping accommodations for rent to the general public, either on a transient or permanent residence basis, either maintaining a minimum of thirty (30) rooms available for rent and having one (1) or more public dining rooms with kitchen facilities as required for an eating establishment, or maintaining less than thirty (30) rooms, but at least three (3) rooms which are available for rent, having at least one (1) public dining room with kitchen facilities as required for an eating establishment, and deriving gross sales from the sale of prepared food items in an amount exceeding its gross sales from the sale of alcoholic beverages. A motel meeting the qualifications set out in this definition shall be deemed a hotel. A hotel may grant a franchise or lease to a third party for the operation of an establishment pursuant to a license within the hotel, and such establishment shall still be treated as part of the hotel. Indoor commercial recreational establishment means a business establishment open to the public which regularly serves prepared food during every hour it is open for business, and which derives at least seventy (70) percent of its total annual gross sales from sales of prepared food and other goods and services other than alcoholic beverages, with the sale of alcoholic beverages being incidental to the establishment's primary business activity at the location. The primary business activity shall be offering a recreational activity such as, but not limited to, dinner theaters, bowling centers, bingo parlors, and other similar activities. Outdoor recreational activities, dance halls, nightclubs, taverns, video arcades, skating arenas, adult entertainment and/or sexually related entertainment and similar activities are specifically excluded from this definition. License means a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter. Licensee means the person to whom a license under this chapter is issued. Liter means the metric measurement currently used by the United States. Main entrance door means the principal entrance by which access may be obtained to the operational area of a structure. In the case of a city park or playground or other similar facility which does not have a principal entrance to a structure, this term shall mean the main entrance gate to the facility. Outdoor commercial recreational establishment means a business establishment, the primary business of which is offering outdoor recreational activities and/or outdoor sports spectator activities to members of the public or members of the establishment if it is a private club, and which regularly serves prepared food during every hour in which it is open for business, and which derives at least seventy (70) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of its recreational activities, sports spectator activities, prepared food and other goods and services other than alcoholic beverages, with the sale of alcoholic beverages being incidental to the establishment's primary business activity at that location. The primary business activity shall be offering an outdoor recreational activity or sports spectator activity such as, but not limited to, golf courses, golf training centers and/or driving 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 46/414 ranges, tennis facilities, swimming facilities, automobile race tracks, fishing facilities and other similar activities. Adult entertainment and/or sexual entertainment facilities are specifically excluded from this definition. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel or other original consumer container. Premises means a physically identifiable place of business of one (1) or more contiguous rooms, operating under the same trade name, where alcoholic beverages are sold. In hotels and private clubs, the premises shall include eating areas, ballrooms, meeting facilities, reception rooms, guest rooms and patio areas of such hotel or private club located within the boundaries of the land on which such hotel or private club is built. Private club means any nonprofit corporation or association organized under the laws of this state which: (1) Has been in existence at least one (1) year prior to filing an application for a license; (2) Has at least seventy-five (75) regular dues-paying members; and (3) Owns, hires or leases a building or space within a building for the reasonable use of its members, which building or space: a. Has suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment; b. Is staffed with a sufficient number of employees for cooking, preparing and serving meals for its members and guests; and c. Has no member, officer, agent or employee directly or indirectly receiving, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits for the sale of alcoholic beverages beyond a "fixed salary," as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 3-7-1, as amended from time to time. Retail consumption dealer means any person holding the appropriate license who sells at retail, only to consumers and not for resale, alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises. Retail package dealer means any person holding the appropriate license who sells at retail, only to consumers and not for resale, alcoholic beverages in unbroken packages for consumption off the premises. School building means only the state, county or church school buildings and buildings at other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of the state and the surrounding property or campus which is directly incorporated into such uses, provided that schools other than state or county schools must be in compliance with the county zoning ordinances. A school must have its property zoned as school property prior to asserting any rights as a school with respect to this chapter. Wholesaler or wholesale dealer means any person holding the appropriate license who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail package dealers or to retail consumption dealers. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 47/414 Wine means any alcoholic beverage made from fruits, berries or grapes which contain not more than twenty-one (21) percent alcohol, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. This term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, sake, rectified wines, etc. This term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at the point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to this definition. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-103. - Adding to, refilling container; misrepresentation. No person shall add to or permit another to add to any original container of an alcoholic beverage another substance or additional alcoholic beverage, or refill any alcoholic beverage container in any manner, or misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-104. - Employment of underage persons prohibited; exceptions. (a) No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under eighteen (18) years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for any alcoholic beverage. (b) The provisions of this section shall not prohibit persons under eighteen (18) years of age who are employed in supermarkets, grocery stores, convenience stores, gasoline stations or other licensees whose principal business is other than the sale of alcoholic beverages from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (c) No person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age shall work as an entertainer in any establishment operated pursuant to a license under this chapter without written consent from his parents or guardian. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-105. - Sale or possession without proper identification prohibited. Each licensee under this chapter shall require and properly check identification of any person seeking to purchase an alcoholic beverage to ensure that no underage person is sold or served an alcoholic beverage or has in his possession an alcoholic beverage while on the premises of the licensee. "Identification" shall mean and include any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, but not be limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license or state department of public safety identification card. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-106. - Restriction of sales; violation; penalty. (a) No licensee or his agents or employees shall do any of the following: (1) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 48/414 Knowingly sell, furnish or cause to be furnished alcoholic beverages to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. (2) Knowingly sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished any alcoholic beverages to any person who is noticeably intoxicated, or who is of unsound mind or who is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to such licensee or his agents or employees. (3) Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished alcoholic beverages or permit alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises of the licensee on any day or at any time when the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by law. (b) The penalty for violation of this section shall be as follows: (1) For the first offense within a period of thirty-six (36) consecutive months, a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or a suspension of the license issued under this chapter held by the licensee for the location where the offense occurred for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. (2) For the second offense at the same location within a period of thirty-six (36) consecutive months, a fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or confinement in the city or county jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days and/or a suspension of the license for the location where the second offense occurred for a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days. (3) For the third offense at the same location within any period of not less than thirty-six (36) consecutive months, a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or confinement in the city or county jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days and/or suspension of the license issued under this chapter held by the licensee for the location where the third offense occurred for a period of not more than three hundred sixty (360) days, or revocation of the license issued under this chapter held by the licensee for the location where the third offense occurred. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-107. - Purchase or possession by underage persons. (a) No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall purchase or knowingly possess any alcoholic beverage. Upon being charged with such offense, where appropriate, the department of public safety shall notify the offender's parents by telephone or by certified mail, return receipt requested, of such offense. (b) No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall attempt to purchase or possess any alcoholic beverage or misrepresent his age in any manner for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages. Upon being charged with 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 49/414 such offense, where appropriate, the department of public safety shall notify the offender's parents by telephone or by certified mail, return receipt requested, of such offense. (c) Any person who violates any provision of this section may, upon conviction, be subject to penalties as set forth in section 1-8 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-108. - Copy of building plans to be submitted with application; approval and maintenance of premises. Each application for a license under this chapter must have submitted with it a copy of the plans of the building in which the proposed establishment will be located. If the construction of the building has not been completed at the time of the filing of the application, a copy of the building permit must also be provided. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all ordinances of the city, regulations of the state revenue commissioners and the state. If a license is issued relating to an establishment located in a building, the construction of which is not complete at the date of such issuance, the license shall be subject to the condition that the building must be approved by the building inspector when completed. Each applicant for a license shall submit with the application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building, or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. If the applicant is a franchisee, such applicant shall submit with the application a copy of the franchise agreement. All facilities for which a license shall be issued shall have adequate sanitary toilet facilities and shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passageways and open areas may be clearly seen by the customers in such facility. The licensee shall maintain the premises, the building in which the premises is located and the surrounding grounds and parking areas in a neat, clean and well maintained condition and appearance, free of trash, litter and any unsightly conditions at all times. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-109. - Election day sales. The sale of alcoholic beverages on any election day is authorized; provided, however, no alcoholic beverages shall be sold on primary or election days within two hundred fifty (250) feet of any polling place or the outer edge of any building within which such polling place is established. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-110. - Establishments operated under licenses issued and outstanding pursuant to prior ordinances; currently outstanding licenses; exceptions for prior establishments. (a) All licenses issued by the city for the sale of beer and/or which are outstanding on January 1, 2003, the effective date of this chapter, shall continue in effect until they expire according to the terms of such licenses. Upon the expiration of such licenses, new renewal licenses must be obtained pursuant to the terms of this chapter. Establishments operating under such currently issued licenses shall be operated after January 1, 2003, the effective date of this chapter, in accordance with all of the applicable requirements of this chapter. (b) No holder of a license to sell beer and/or wine in the city, either for on-premises consumption or in packages for off-premises consumption, issued pursuant to any ordinance which preceded this chapter, which license was in effect on January 1, 2003, the effective date of this chapter, actually operating a business pursuant to such license shall be denied a license for the same type and scope of operations as were being carried on at such date due to the fact that such business does not qualify as an eating establishment, hotel, indoor commercial recreational establishment or private club. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 50/414 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-111. - Violation; penalties. The penalties for any violation of this chapter, unless otherwise specified in this chapter, shall be as follows: (1) For any violation which is also a violation of the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code (O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.), a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or imprisonment in the city or county jail for a period not to exceed one (1) year; (2) For any other violation of this chapter, such penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-8; and (3) In addition to the penalties set forth in subsections (1) and (2) of this section and totally distinct and separate from such penalties, any violation of this chapter or any failure to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of any or all licenses issued under this chapter held by the licensee, regardless of the number of licenses or locations involved and regardless of whether or not the licensee knew of or contributed to such violation. It is the intent of this subsection, without limiting its generality, to grant to the city council the right to suspend or revoke any and all licenses held by a licensee when any violation of this chapter occurs at any place of business operated by the licensee pursuant to a license. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-112. - Repeal of conflicting ordinances. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this chapter are expressly repealed. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Secs. 3-113—3-145. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LICENSES FOOTNOTE(S): (5) State Law reference— Local permit or license required for wholesale or retail sales of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(a); governing authority to set forth ascertainable standards pertaining to the granting, refusal, suspension or revocation of alcoholic beverage permits or licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(b)(1); local license required for wholesale or retail sales of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 3-146. - Required for sale or possession for sale. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverage when such person is not operating pursuant to a license to sell or possess for sale such alcoholic beverages, or to sell any alcoholic beverage in violation of the terms of the license or of this article. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-147. - Separate application and license required for each location of sale; jointly held license for concessions and similar arrangements. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 51/414 (a) Each license under this article shall be limited to the operation of an establishment or enterprise for the sale of alcoholic beverages at a specific location as set forth in the license. Separate applications must be made and separate licenses must be obtained for each location at which an activity requiring a license is conducted. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer from catering or supplying a private party or gathering being put on by a third party at a location other than that covered by the license. (b) For a retail consumption dealer, if the sale of alcoholic beverages within an establishment or business at a specific location is handled through a concession contract, the license for such location shall be obtained jointly in the name of the entity which operates the business or establishment within which such concession is located and the name of the entity operating the concession. A "concession contract," for purposes of this subsection, shall mean an agreement or arrangement where the person selling alcoholic beverages is doing so as a department or section of a larger business enterprise, for example, a beverage service operated within a hotel, food and beverage services operated within an indoor commercial recreational establishment or outdoor commercial recreational establishment, or a beverage service operated within an eating establishment. For purposes of determining whether a particular business enterprise qualifies as an eating establishment, hotel, indoor commercial recreational establishment or an outdoor commercial recreational establishment, the activities, facilities and sales of the business enterprise as a whole shall be aggregated, and the individual sales or facilities of any concession therein shall not be treated separately. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-148. - Application procedure. (a) A person desiring to obtain a license under this article shall make application to the city clerk on the forms prescribed by the city clerk. (b) The application shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (1) The name and address of the applicant and the proposed business to be carried on; (2) If a partnership, the names and residence addresses of all of the partners unless there are more than twenty (20) partners, in which case the application shall list all partners having, directly or indirectly, at least a five-percent interest in the assets or revenues of the partnership; (3) If a corporation, the names and residence addresses of the officers, the directors, the registered agent for service of process, the manager of the business for which the license is sought and all shareholders unless there are more than twenty (20) shareholders, in which case the application shall list all shareholders holding at least five (5) percent of the capital stock of the corporation; and (4) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 52/414 If a private club, the names and residence addresses of the officers, directors and the manager of such private club. (c) All applicants shall furnish data, fingerprints, evidence of financial responsibility in the form of a bond in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or insurance with a minimum coverage of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per incident, a copy of the current city business license for the establishment, certification from the tax commissioner that all taxes due to the city and county by the applicant have been paid and other material as required by the city clerk. Failure to furnish such data as required by the city clerk shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the application. (d) Each application for an initial license as opposed to a license renewal shall have attached thereto a plat of the land on which the establishment is proposed to be located showing the location of the improvements thereon. Such plat must be prepared by a land surveyor registered under the laws of the state and the surveyor shall show on the plat and certify as to the accuracy thereof the distance from the main entrance door of the proposed establishment to any school building, church building, city park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility located within five hundred (500) yards thereof measured under the applicable provisions of section 3-152 (e) All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths. (f) An application shall be presented to the city council or a committee designated by the city council within fortyfive (45) days after the date such application is deemed complete by the city clerk. The city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing of the date on which the application will be presented to the city council or its designated committee, which notice shall be given in sufficient time to enable the applicant to meet the public notice requirements as set forth in section 3-151 (g) At the time the application is presented to the city council or its designated committee, the applicant may appear and present any matters in support of the application and any other person may appear and present matters in opposition to the application. Upon hearing all of the presentations, the city council or its designated committee shall take action denying or granting the application or deferring action for a period not to exceed forty-five (45) days in order to obtain further information. If the application is denied, the city council or its designated committee shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for the denial. (h) In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant may not reapply for a similar license for the same location for at least one (1) year from the date of such denial. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-149. - Withdrawal of application; refund of fees. Any application for a license made pursuant to this article may be withdrawn by the applicant at any time. If the application is withdrawn before the license is issued, any sums deposited as license fees will be refunded. After issuance of a license, no refunds will be made. No refunds shall be made under any circumstances for investigation and administrative fees required in this article. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 53/414 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-150. - Licensing qualifications. (a) A license under this article will be issued only to a person who is a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States. Where an applicant is other than a natural person, such applicant must be an entity organized and existing under the laws of the United States or one (1) of its states, and the natural persons who are required to join in the application must meet the qualifications of this subsection. (b) For a license to be issued to a general partnership, the application must be made jointly by the partnership, any managing partner and all other partners owning at least a twenty-percent interest in the assets or revenues of the partnership. If there is no managing partner, nor a partner meeting the ownership requirements, the application then must be made jointly in the name of the partnership and the general partner owning the greatest percentage interest in the assets and revenues of the partnership. At least one (1) of the applicants shall be a natural person. If none of the applicants required in this subsection is a natural person, then the natural person having primary responsibility for the operation of the business for which the license is sought shall join in the application. (c) Where the applicant for a license is a limited partnership, the application shall be made jointly by the limited partnership, its general partner and any other partner, limited or general, owning at least a twenty-percent interest in the assets or revenues of the limited partnership. At least one (1) of the applicants must be a natural person. If none of the applicants required in this subsection is a natural person, then the natural person having primary responsibility for the operation of the business for which the license is sought shall join in the application. (d) Where the applicant for a license is a corporation, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the corporation and its president or vice-president and any stockholder owning at least twenty (20) percent of the total outstanding capital stock of the corporation. (e) Where the applicant for a license is a private club, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the private club and its president or general manager. (f) Where the applicant for a license is an entity other than a natural person, partnership, corporation or private club, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the entity, the natural person having chief executive officer authority over the business activities of the entity and any other person having at least a five-percent interest in the assets or revenues of the entity. The application shall further disclose the type of entity making the application and every person having an ownership interest in the assets or revenues of the entity. (g) Licenses issued to corporations, general partnerships, limited partnerships, private clubs or other types of entities must be issued jointly to the entity and all of the other persons required by this section to join in the application. (h) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 54/414 No person shall be granted a license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the city council or its designated committee that such person shall be of good moral character or, in the case of an entity which is not a natural person, that such entity has a good reputation, and in no event shall a license be granted to any person who has been convicted or has pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any charge involving a crime of moral turpitude, gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or illegal possession of alcoholic beverages within a period of ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of such application. In the case of a partnership, corporation, private club or other business entity, a license shall not be issued to the partnership, corporation, private club or other entity if any partner, officer, director, shareholder or other person required to be listed on the application, even if such person is not required to be a joint applicant, cannot meet the requirements as set forth in this subsection in the same manner as though such individual was the applicant. At the time an application is submitted for a license, the applicant shall, by a duly sworn affidavit, certify that all of the requirements of this section have been met by the applicant and the other persons required to be listed on the application as set forth in this subsection. Should any person in whose name a license is issued or any person whose name is required to be listed on the application for a license under this article, after the license has been issued, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a charge involving a crime of moral turpitude, gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or illegal possession of alcoholic beverages, the license shall be immediately revoked and cancelled. (i) No license under this article shall be issued to any person convicted or pleading guilty or nolo contendere to any charge under any federal, state or local law constituting a felony within ten (10) years prior to the date of the filing of the application for such license. (j) No license under this article shall be issued to any person who has had any license issued under the police powers of any city or county revoked within two (2) years prior to the filing of the application for a license under this article. (k) The city council or its designated committee may decline to issue a license under this article when any person having any ownership interest in or control over the land or building in which the establishment to be operated pursuant to the license will be located does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section for the licensee. (l) If a person in whose name a license under this article is issued is not a county resident, such person must appoint and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this article may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. If the licensee is not a natural person, it will be required to appoint and maintain a registered agent in the county if it does not have in the county any agent upon whom process can legally be served for such entity under the laws of the state. The licensee shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of such agent, with the city clerk. (m) An application for a license under this article may be denied where it appears to the city council or its designated committee that the applicant does not have adequate financial strength, adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended or is likely to be a surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license under this article. (n) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 55/414 The city council or its designated committee, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the establishment. If, in the city council's or the committee's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-151. - Public notice of application for new license. A person filing an application for a new license under this article as opposed to an application for the renewal of an existing license shall give public notice of the filing of the application as follows: (1) By publishing a notice of the application in the newspaper in which sheriff's sales in the county are placed, in a form approved by the city clerk, three (3) times in the thirty (30) days preceding the consideration of the application by the city council; (2) By posting a sign for at least thirty (30) days preceding the consideration of the application by the city council in a prominent position on the property where it can be readily read from the road, which states: "Application has been made to the city council for a license to sell (beer) (wine) (distilled spirits) for consumption (on) (off) premises at this location." Date: ____________ Name of Applicant ____________ ____________ The applicant must provide the city council proof of the giving of such public notice at or prior to the city council's consideration of the application. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-152. - Distance requirements. (a) No establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article shall be located in a building which is closer than one hundred (100) yards to a church building, library, daycare, children's nursery, or an alcoholic treatment facility, or closer than two hundred (200) yards to a school building. In applying this section, the city council shall determine what property is included in a school building, church building, city park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility consistent with the definitions set forth in section 3-102, and the determination of the city council shall be final. (b) For purposes of this section, subject to the qualifications set forth in this subsection, distances shall be measured in a straight line from the main entrance door of the establishment for which the license under this article is being sought to the nearest point on the boundary line of the land making up the campus of the church building, school 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 56/414 building, or alcoholic treatment facility. All lots and parcels of land bordering on Wrightsboro Road at the edge of the city limits up to and including the intersection of Wrightsboro Road and Robinson Avenue is hereby declared to be a "special commercial growth center" only for the purposes of complying with this article. As such all distances from any church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility which is built, acquired or established after December 31, 2002, or in the case of areas added to the designated areas which are built, acquired or established after the effective date of such designation, distance shall be measured from the main entrance door of the establishment for which a license is being sought to the nearest point of the centerline of the nearest traveled road, street or highway, then measured along such centerline to a point on the centerline nearest the main entrance door of the school building, church building, or alcoholic treatment facility and then measured in a straight line from such centerline to such main entrance door. If any church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility located in one (1) of the designated areas on December 31, 2002 or the effective date of designation of an area added to the designated areas after December 31, 2002, as the case may be, thereafter has added to its campus additional land, measurement of the distance requirements shall continue to be made as provided in the first sentence of this subsection (b), but the land acquired after December 31, 2002, or the effective designation date, as the case may be, shall not be considered to be part of the land or campus of the church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility. (c) No establishment which is being operated pursuant to a city license to sell beer and/or wine on January 1, 2003, the effective date of this article, shall be denied continued operation under such existing license, nor denied any renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of such establishment be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. Upon cessation of the operation of the establishment as set forth in section 3-156 pursuant to such license, such exemption shall cease. (d) If the distance requirements in this section are met at the time of issuance of a license under this article, the subsequent opening and operation of a church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility within the distances prohibited in this section shall not prevent the continued operation of the establishment pursuant to the license or the renewal of the license or the issuance of a new license to any subsequent owner of such establishment as long as the business operation of the establishment does not cease as set forth in section 3-156 (e) The holder of title to any property making up a church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility may waive the distance requirements of this section as they apply to such facility in any specific instance by recording in the real estate records in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county, a written instrument evidencing such waiver and setting out the terms thereof, which instrument shall be executed and witnessed with the same formalities as a deed filed for record in the clerk's office. (f) Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city council from amending this section, adding additional special commercial growth centers nor amending any distance requirements in the future. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-153. - Administrative and investigative fees. (a) Upon making application for a license under this article, the applicant shall pay a license fee for the license, an administrative and investigative fee and such other fees as may be established from time to time by the city council by resolution adopted in open meeting and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The initial schedule 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 57/414 of fees shall be adopted and is attached to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Ordinance adopted January 1, 2003. Such schedule of fees shall remain in effect until amended by the city council. All applicants shall be furnished a copy of the schedule of fees at the time of application for a license under this article. In addition, all fees and taxes due the state, city, and/or county by the applicant, or upon the property on which the establishment is to be located, must be paid in full at or prior to the time of filing the application for the license. (b) All licenses granted under this article shall be for a calendar year and the full license fee must be paid for a license application at the time of the filing of the application. (c) Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate certified check in the amount of the applicable investigate and administrative fees. If the applicant is denied a state license, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the investigative and administrative fees shall be retained. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-154. - Display at place of business. A license issued under this article shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to public view at the place of business for which the license was granted. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-155. - Transferability. (a) No license under this article shall be transferable, except as otherwise provided in this section. (b) In case of the death of a licensee who is the sole licensee, the establishment for which the license was issued shall be allowed to continue to sell alcoholic beverages in accordance with the terms of the license for a period of forty-five (45) days from the date of death of the licensee or until approval of a new licensee, whichever shall first occur; provided, however, that no sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed after the seventh day after the date of death of the licensee until such time as a personal representative of the estate of the deceased licensee, appointed by a probate court of competent jurisdiction, shall have registered with the city clerk on forms prepared by the city clerk. Such personal representative shall be subject to all of the requirements that applied to the deceased licensee, and shall agree in writing to operate the establishment during the interim period in accordance with the terms of the license and the laws of the state and city. (c) In the case of licenses issued jointly to partnerships and certain partners, corporations and certain officers or stockholders, private clubs and certain officers or other entities and certain persons related thereto as set forth in section 3-150, if one (1) of the joint holders of such a license severs his association with the establishment operated pursuant to the license, the establishment may continue to sell alcoholic beverages for a period of fortyfive (45) days from the date determined by the city clerk to be the date of severance, provided no such sale shall be authorized until such time as an application to substitute the person taking the place of the departing person as a joint holder of the license is made by the appropriate person. If the change is one which results from a change in control of the licensee, partnership, corporation or other business entity, then an application for a new license 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 58/414 must be filed. Upon issuance of a new license, the authorization to sell under the previous license shall be revoked by operation of law. (d) Any change in the ownership of a licensee which is not a natural person which would change the ownership information furnished on the most recently updated application for the license must be reported to the city clerk within ten (10) days following the occurrence of such change in ownership. If such change in ownership results in an additional person being required to be a joint licensee under section 3-148, or an additional person being listed on the application, but not as a joint licensee, the license may be revoked if any such person fails to meet the qualifications required by this article. If such change in ownership results in a change in control of the business entity which is a joint licensee, then a new application must be filed for the issuance of a new license. If an application for a new license is filed within seven (7) days of the date on which the change in control occurred, then the establishment may continue to operate under the old license for a period of forty-five (45) days from the date of the change in control or until the new license is issued or denied, whichever shall occur first. (e) If substantially all of the assets of an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article are sold, conveyed or otherwise transferred by the licensee, and if an application for a new license is filed with the city clerk within seven (7) days of such sale or transfer, the establishment may continue to be operated under the then existing license for a period of forty-five (45) days or until a new license is issued or denied to the new owner, whichever shall occur first. (f) Under no circumstances shall a license be transferred where the original holder of the license is under suspension. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-156. - Automatic forfeiture for nonuse. Any licensee who shall, for a period of two (2) consecutive months after the license under this article has been issued, cease to operate the business of selling alcoholic beverages as authorized in the license shall, after the two-month period, automatically forfeit the license without the necessity of any further action. If the business operation of selling alcoholic beverages is interrupted as a result of damage to the premises which is being repaired or because the premises is being remodeled, then this section shall not apply to such cessation of operation. If a license is issued for the operation of an establishment in a building which has not yet been completed, the license will not be forfeited unless the licensee fails to begin operations within a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of issuance of the license. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-157. - Expiration; renewal. (a) All licenses granted under this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file application with the city clerk on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed on or before October 31 of each year. If a renewal application is received after October 31, the city cannot assure the applicant that a renewal license will be issued by January 1 and the licensee will have to cease the sale of alcoholic beverages from January 1 until the renewal license is issued. If a license renewal application is received after December 31, such application shall be treated 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 59/414 as an application for a new license and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules, regulations and fees for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been issued. (b) Any person applying for renewal of a license must pay the license, administrative and investigative fees at the time of filing the application. Failure to pay such fees at that time shall result in the application for renewal being treated as not filed or withdrawn. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-158. - Audits. The city clerk, in order to determine if the provisions of this chapter are being complied with or to determine the eligibility of an applicant, may require a licensee or an applicant for a license under this article to provide the city clerk with audited financial statements of the licensee or applicant for such period as the city clerk may determine. The city clerk shall also have the authority to conduct an audit of the books and records of a licensee or an applicant. If the city clerk deems it necessary to conduct such an audit, the city clerk shall so notify the licensee or applicant of the date, time and place of the audit. The city clerk shall designate the person to perform such audit. The licensee shall cooperate with such audit or forfeit all licenses issued under this article. If an applicant for a license fails to cooperate with an audit, the application shall be deemed withdrawn. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-159. - Collection of delinquent sums. If any person shall fail to pay any sum due under this chapter, the city clerk or his/her designee shall issue an execution against the delinquent person and his property for the amount of the delinquent fee or tax. The failure to pay any taxes or fees shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and the license of the business to sell alcohol shall be suspended immediately. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-160. - Licensee to maintain copies of regulations; responsibility for instruction; violations. Each licensee shall keep a copy of this chapter, the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code and any regulations issued under such code on the premises.
