The licensee shall instruct any employee or agent of the licensee working in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages as to the requirements of all laws and regulations applicable to such sales so that the licensee, his agents and employees selling alcoholic beverages shall at all times be familiar with the requirements of the laws and regulations applicable to such sales. The licensee shall be responsible for any acts of his agents or employees which are in violation of this chapter or of the laws of the state or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-161. - Suspension, revocation. (a) A license under this article may be suspended or revoked by the city council when the licensee furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information on the application or any renewal application for a license, or for failure of the licensee to pay all fees, taxes or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter or other laws or ordinances of the city or state. (b) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 60/414 Whenever the state shall revoke or suspend any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the license issued under this article shall be automatically revoked or suspended, as the case may be. (c) If the city clerk, the city council or its designated committee believes that probable cause exists to find that a violation of sections 3-106, 3-188 and/or 3-194 has occurred in an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article, the city council or its designated committee may temporarily suspend such license pending final determination and action on the matter by the city council or its designated committee. (d) The city clerk shall revoke all of the licenses of any licensee under this article who has had three or more suspensions or revocations of a license, including all of his licenses in any consecutive thirty-six-month period. (e) The city clerk shall revoke a license under this article where alcoholic beverages have been sold or distributed at the location covered by the license during a period of suspension of such license. (f) The city council may suspend or revoke any license under this article when the licensee does not meet the licensing qualifications set forth in this article and such information becomes known to the city clerk or the city council. (g) An act or omission of a licensee under this article, by the owner of a twenty (20) percent or more interest in an establishment operated pursuant to a license, the manager of an establishment operated pursuant to a license or an employee of the establishment operated pursuant to a license working in some aspect of the sale of alcoholic beverages who willingly or knowingly performed any act, which constitutes a violation of federal or state law or this chapter will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license when the city council determines that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues; provided, however, that in the case of a manager or employee, the city council must determine that the acts of the manager or employee were known to or, under reasonable circumstances, should have been known to the licensee, or were condoned by the licensee, or that the licensee had not established reasonable practices or procedures to prevent such act or omission from occurring. (h) A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the city council determines that a licensee no longer maintains adequate financial strength or responsibility upon which issuance of the license was based or whenever the licensee has defaulted in any obligation of any kind whatsoever lawfully owing to the city. (i) A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the city council determines that the establishment operated pursuant to the license has been the scene of repeated incidents of violence resulting in injury to a person or damage to property or a disturbance of the peace or requiring the intervention of law enforcement officers on the scene of a single incident of severe violence resulting in the death of a person or serious injury to a person requiring inpatient hospital care for the injured person. (j) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 61/414 Upon completion of any period of suspension, a license under this article shall not be reinstated until the licensee has paid the city a reinstatement fee equal to the original license fee for that calendar year. In addition, the licensee shall pay the administrative and investigative fees and update all license application forms. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-162. - Hearings. (a) Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, or unless waived by the licensee, no license under this article shall be suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. (b) The city clerk shall provide written notice to the licensee of the initiation of an action to suspend or revoke a license. Such written notification shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for such action and shall notify the licensee of the right to a hearing under the provisions of this section. Any licensee against whom action for the suspension or revocation of a license is initiated may have a hearing concerning such action before the city council or a committee thereof designated by the city council. Such hearing shall be by written request, filed in the office of the city clerk within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice of the initiation of the action from the city clerk to the licensee. Such written request shall set forth the reasons why the licensee feels that the proposed action should not be taken and, in reasonable detail, the grounds and facts which the licensee contends support the licensee's position. The city council shall determine whether or not the license shall be temporarily suspended during the period prior to the hearing and until action is taken by the city council or its designated committee. Failure of the licensee to request a hearing within the time specified shall be deemed to be a waiver by the licensee of a right to a hearing, and the city council shall be authorized to proceed with final action on the matter without the holding of a hearing. (c) The city council, by resolution, may assign the duties of conducting a hearing to a committee of the city council. The committee's action shall be final. (d) A hearing, if requested, shall be held within forty-five (45) days of the date of filing the request for a hearing with the city clerk. At such hearing the licensee shall have the right to be represented by an attorney, at the expense of the licensee, and to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. (e) The action of the city council or its committee shall be forwarded to the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after the conclusion of the hearing, and the city clerk shall notify the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the action taken by the city council or its committee. (f) The action of the city council or its committee shall be final when taken. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-163. - Notice. For the purpose of this chapter, notice shall be deemed to be delivered when such notice is personally served, served upon the licensee's registered agent, or, if mailed, it must be mailed to the licensee at the address given in 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 62/414 the latest application for the license under this article by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall be deemed delivered on the third business day after the date of deposit in the United States mail. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Secs. 3-164—3-185. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS REGULATIONS Sec. 3-186. - Outdoor advertising. (a) No outdoor advertising or signs promoting the sale of alcoholic beverages or the prices thereof shall be permitted on the premises of any establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article. (b) Wholesale dealers may place wall-mounted signs on the principal building advertising the name of the company and brands sold at wholesale. Such signs must otherwise comply with city ordinances regulating signs. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-187. - Sale of beverages by indoor and outdoor commercial recreational establishments. (a) A retail consumption dealer which is an indoor commercial recreational establishment shall not sell alcoholic beverages at any time that such dealer is having a promotion or event for which it can reasonably be anticipated that in excess of fifty (50) percent of those persons attending will be under twenty-one (21) years of age. (b) A retail consumption dealer which is an outdoor commercial recreational establishment shall not sell alcoholic beverages at any time that such dealer is having a promotion or event for which it can reasonably be anticipated that in excess of fifty (50) percent of those persons attending will be under twenty-one (21) years of age. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-188. - Gambling prohibited on the premises of retail consumption dealers. There shall be no gambling, betting, lotteries, games of chance or the operation of any scheme for hazarding money or any other thing of value on the premises of any retail consumption dealer. No retail consumption dealer shall permit in his establishment slot machines, pinball machines or similar machines which require a federal gambling stamp. Notwithstanding anything in this division to the contrary, this section shall not prohibit the sale on the premises of any retail consumption dealer of state lottery tickets, cards or games which are legally sold under the laws of the state. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-189. - Open area and patio sales. (a) Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a retail consumption dealer in a patio/open area type environment if the retail consumption dealer has been approved to do so by the city clerk. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 63/414 (b) To obtain such approval, the patio/open area must be enclosed by a permanent structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main structure on the premises covered by the license. The purpose of this requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink container without the licensee's knowledge. (c) The height of the enclosing structure shall be a minimum of four (4) feet above ground level. Such enclosing structure does not have to be solid, nor does it have to restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area. Such enclosing structure must be permitted and approved by the engineering services department. (d) There must be an approved emergency fire exit (not for general public use unless an emergency exists) from the patio/open sales area which should be of the type that sounds an alarm so that the licensee will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. (e) If a licensee desires a patio/open sales area inside an existing structure, plans will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis by the city clerk. Interior-type patio/open sales areas must also meet the requirements of the city's planning, zoning, engineering and fire codes, and any applicable codes of the state. (f) Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, if the retail consumption dealer is an outdoor commercial recreational establishment, alcoholic beverage sales can be made outdoors in the open, provided that such alcoholic beverages must be consumed on the premises of the outdoor commercial recreational establishment and may not be carried off of such premises. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-190. - Outside consumption prohibited; exception. (a) No person shall leave the building in which alcoholic beverages are sold with open alcoholic beverage containers unless such person is in a patio/open sales area which is approved in accordance with section 3-189. It is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open alcoholic beverage containers are carried out of the building in violation of this section. (b) People shall not gather outside any building in which alcoholic beverages are sold and consume alcoholic beverages or loiter and mill about. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee operating the business in such building to prevent such gatherings. (c) Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, a person purchasing an alcoholic beverage at an outdoor commercial recreational establishment which is a retail consumption dealer may leave the building in which such alcoholic beverage is sold and may consume such alcoholic beverage outdoors or may purchase and consume such alcoholic beverage outdoors, provided that the alcoholic beverage must be consumed on the premises of the outdoor commercial recreational establishment and may not be carried off of such premises. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 64/414 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-191. - Solicitation. A retail consumption dealer shall not require, permit, suffer, encourage or induce any employee or person to solicit on the premises, for himself or for any person other than the patron and guest of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether an alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-192. - Happy hours or similar promotions. (a) No retail consumption dealer, his employees or agents, in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall: (1) Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person; (2) Deliver more than one (1) alcoholic beverage to one (1) person at a time; (3) Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished to any person an unlimited number of alcoholic beverages during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; (4) Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without proportionately increasing the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage; (5) Encourage or permit on the premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize; and (6) Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished any alcoholic beverages for a price less than the cost of the ingredients to the licensee. (b) No retail consumption dealer shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a) of this section. (c) Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit retail consumption dealers from offering free food or entertainment at any time, or to prohibit the retail consumption dealer from including an alcoholic beverage as part of a meal package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe, or pitchers or buckets of beer. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 65/414 Sec. 3-193. - Restriction of noise. Noise levels above those otherwise allowed by city ordinances shall not be permitted beyond the boundaries of the land on which facilities operated pursuant to a license under this article are located. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-194. - Certain types of entertainment, attire and conduct prohibited. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are not permitted in or at any establishment operating pursuant to a license under this article: (1) The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, or of any portion of a person's pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or genitals; (2) Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner set forth in subsection (1) of this section, or where any person performs acts of or acts which simulate: a. Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; b. The touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals; or c. The displaying of any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, or any portion of a person's pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. (3) The use of artificial devices or inanimate objects to perform, simulate or depict any of the prohibited conduct or activities set forth in subsection (2) of this section, or the showing of any film, still pictures, electronic reproduction or other visual reproductions depicting any of the acts set forth in subsection (2) of this section; or (4) The holding, promotion or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the prohibited conduct set forth in this section. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-195. - Inspection of licensed establishments. Officers of the department of public safety and health department and the fire marshal shall have the authority to inspect an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article during the hours in which the 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 66/414 establishment is open for business. Such inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other city officer to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of this Code. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-196. - Closing establishment in case of emergency. The director of the department of public safety or the city clerk, or their designees, may immediately close an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article in case of an emergency, for the safety of the public or to investigate a crime for a period of time not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours, or for such longer period of time as law enforcement officials may reasonably require to complete a criminal investigation at the establishment. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-197. - Bringing alcoholic beverages into establishments. No person shall bring his own alcoholic beverages into any commercial establishment regardless of whether or not such establishment is operated pursuant to a license under this article. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-198. - Consumption on-premises of distilled spirits; locations where permitted. A license for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises will be issued only for an eating establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment or a private club. When eating establishments are located in hotels, shopping malls or high-rise office or apartment buildings, every public entrance to the eating establishment shall be from the outside or a public lobby, hallway, mall or other publicly used interior portion of the primary use structure. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-199. - Hours and days of sale of distilled spirits. (a) Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. until 1:55 a.m. on Monday through Saturday morning at 1:55 a.m. and from 9:00 a.m. Saturday until 11:55 p.m. on Saturday. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on premises is permitted on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging. (b) Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises at any time in violation of any local ordinance or regulation, or of any special order of the city council. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02; Ord. No. 173-02, § 1, 2-12-06) Sec. 3-200. - Consumption sales only of distilled spirits. Persons holding a license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to make any package sales of alcoholic beverages on such premises. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 67/414 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-201. - Drinks to be served by employees. Alcoholic beverages sold by the drink must be served by employees of the licensee within the premises covered by the license. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-202. - Storage of inventory. A retail consumption dealer must keep his inventory of alcoholic beverages only on the premises covered by his license. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-203. - Beer and wine consumption on-premises; locations where permitted. No license for the sale of beer or wine for consumption on the premises will be issued, except for an eating establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment or a private club. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-204. - Hours and days of sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption. (a) Beer and wine shall not be sold for consumption on the premises, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. until 1:55 a.m. on Monday through Saturday morning at 1:55 a.m. and from 9:00 a.m. Saturday until 11:55 p.m. on Saturday. (b) No beer and/or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises at any time in violation of any local ordinance or regulation, or of any special order of the city council. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-205. - Temporary permit for nonprofit civic organizations requirements. Upon filing an application and paying the requisite fees, a nonprofit civic organization may be issued a temporary permit authorizing the organization to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises for a period not to exceed two (2) days. No more than two (2) temporary permits, covering a total of four (4) days, shall be issued to an organization in any calendar year. Nonprofit organizations shall comply with all requirements of this chapter for operations by a retail consumption dealer, except that the alcoholic beverages may be included in the price of admission to the event, no excise taxes shall be paid or collected on such sales, and such other exceptions as the city clerk or the city council or its designated committee may approve. No public notice of the application shall be required for any temporary permit. An application for a temporary permit under this section must be filed not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date for which the temporary permit is sought. Such application shall be made on forms prescribed by the city clerk and shall contain all information required by such forms. The chief executive officer and chief operating officer of the organization must be joint applicants for the temporary permit. All applications for temporary permits under this section must be approved by the city council or its designated committee, who shall have the authority to determine if the applicant is a nonprofit civic organization, and such determination in this regard shall be final. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 68/414 Sec. 3-206. - Package sales. Package sales of malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits shall be allowed on Sunday between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (Ord. No. 215, 12-12-11) Secs. 3-207—3-213. - Reserved. Sec. 3-214. - Wholesale purchase of distilled spirits, beer and wine. (a) No retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer shall purchase any alcoholic beverage from any person other than a wholesaler. No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person other than a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the purchase by one retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer of another retail consumption dealer's or retail package dealer's entire stock in a bona fide purchase of an ongoing business. (b) No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the city, except by a wholesaler. The name of the wholesaler shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-215. - Reserved. Sec. 3-216. - Hotel in-room service. (a) Definition. As used in this section, "in-room service" means the delivery of alcoholic beverages, in unbroken packages, by an employee of a hotel to a registered guest's room when such alcoholic beverages have been ordered by the guest, and the guest will be billed for such alcoholic beverages at the time of delivery, and when the sale of such alcoholic beverages is completed at the time of delivery; and the provision of a cabinet or other facility located in a hotel's guest room which contains alcoholic beverages and which is provided upon written request of the guest, and which is accessible by lock and key only to the guest, and for which the sale of the alcoholic beverages contained in such cabinet or other facility is final at the time requested, except for a credit which may be given to the guest for any unused portion. (b) License. A hotel, if it has a license to sell alcoholic beverages either by the package and/or by the drink, may be authorized by the city council to make similar sales through in-room service. A hotel, prior to providing in-room service, must obtain from the city a license permitting such hotel to provide in-room service of alcoholic beverages. (c) Restrictions and limitations. The sale of alcoholic beverages by in-room service shall be subject to all restrictions and limitations of this chapter relative to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages, except as provided otherwise in this section, and shall be authorized only on such days and during such hours as the sale of the alcoholic beverages in question is otherwise authorized in the city. (d) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 69/414 Package size. Distilled spirits sold through in-room service shall not be sold in packages containing less than two hundred (200) milliliters each. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-217. - Certain government facilities. Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, the city council may permit the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises at such city-owned facilities and under such conditions as the city council may determine from time to time. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Secs. 2-218—2-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES FOOTNOTE(S): (6) State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3- 4-13o; imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. Sec. 3-251. - Retail sales of distilled spirits by the drink. Every purchaser at retail of distilled spirits by the drink in the city shall pay a tax thereon at the rate of three (3) percent of the retail price or charge for such drink, or at such higher rate as may be permitted by the laws of the state. Such tax shall not apply in any portion of the city in which an excise tax on the sale of distilled spirits by the drink is being imposed, levied and collected by a municipality. Such tax shall be collected by the retail consumption dealer, who shall remit such tax to the city clerk on or before the tenth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the retail consumption dealer's gross sales derived from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Credit card sales shall be reported as part of gross sales, and taxes collected on such credit card sales shall be submitted to the city in the same manner as required for cash sales. Each retail consumption dealer shall be allowed a deduction equal to the rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as amended from time to time, provided that such tax is not delinquent at the time of payment. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-252. - Wholesale sales of distilled spirits and wine. There is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, including a proportionate amount calculated at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, on all sales of distilled spirits and wine in the city by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers. Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk by the wholesaler selling such distilled spirits or wine to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the tenth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of distilled spirits and wine in the city during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Wine containing less than one-half (½) of one (1) percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver, in any manner, any distilled spirits or wine to a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer without collecting such tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any distilled spirits or wine on which such tax has not been paid. Each wholesaler shall be paid three (3) percent of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of the tax, provided that the tax is paid on or before its due date. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 70/414 Sec. 3-253. - Wholesale sales of beer. There is levied an excise tax on all beer sold by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers in the city at the highest rate allowed by the state, but not less than the following: (1) Where beer is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, six dollars ($6.00) on each container sold containing not more than fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons; and (2) Where beer is sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of five cents ($0.05) per twelve (12) ounces, and a proportionate rate on all fractional parts of twelve (12) ounces. Beer which contains less than one-half (½) of one (1) percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk by the wholesaler selling the beer to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the tenth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of beer in the city during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-254. - Deficiency determination. (a) Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax to be paid to the city by any person, the city clerk may cause an audit of the books and records of the licensee to be performed and may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the city clerk's possession or that may come into the city clerk's possession. One (1) or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more monthly periods. It shall be the duty of each licensee subject to the collection or payment of any of the excise taxes set forth in this article to keep and preserve his records relative to the collection and payment of such taxes for three (3) years. (b) Interest. The amount of the deficiency determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the tenth day after the close of the monthly period in which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment thereof. (c) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a deficiency determination, the city clerk may offset overpayments for a period against underpayments for another period, penalties and the interest on underpayments. (d) Penalty for negligence or disregard of rules and regulations. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added to the tax. (e) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 71/414 Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provision of sections 3-251—3-256, or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the deficiency shall be added to such tax. (f) Notice of city clerk's determination; service of. The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the licensee written notice of a deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If such service is made by mail, such service shall be made pursuant to section 3-163 (g) Time within which notice is to be mailed. Except in the case of fraud, intent to evade the provisions of this article or authorized rules and regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the tenth day of every month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-255. - Determination if no return made. (a) Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee or of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Upon the basis of such estimate, the city clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to such determined sum a penalty equal to fifteen (15) percent thereof. One (1) or more determinations may be made for one (1) or more periods. (b) Offsetting of overpayments. If making a determination, the city clerk may offset overpayments for a period or penalties against the interest on the underpayments. (c) Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the tenth day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount, or any portion thereof, should have been returned, until the date of payment. (d) Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or an intent to evade sections 3-251—3-256 or rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the amount required to be paid by the person, exclusive of penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the fifteen (15) percent penalty provided in section 3-254(d). (e) Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his determination, the city clerk shall give to the person written notice, to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice in section 3-163 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 72/414 (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02) Sec. 3-256. - Collection. (a) Security. Whenever the city clerk deems it necessary to ensure compliance with sections 3-251—3-256, he may require any person subject to such sections to deposit with him such security as the city clerk may determine. The amount of the security shall be fixed by the city clerk, but shall not be greater than twice the person's estimated average liability for the period for which he files returns, determined in such a manner as the city clerk deems proper, or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), whichever amount is the lesser. The amount of the security may be increased by the city clerk subject to the limitations provided in this section. The city clerk may sell the security at public auction, with the approval of the city council, if it becomes necessary to do so in order to recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served upon the person who deposited the security personally or by mail. If service is by mail, it shall be made in the manner prescribed for service of a notice of determined deficiency and shall be addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. Upon any sale, any surplus above the amounts due shall be returned to the person who deposited the security. (b) Notice of delinquency to persons holding credits or property of delinquent; duty of persons so notified. If any person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be paid by him, or if a delinquency determination has been made against him which remains unpaid, the city clerk may, not later than three (3) years after the payment became delinquent, give notice thereof by registered mail to all persons in the city having in their possession or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the delinquent, or owing any debts to the delinquent. After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither transfer nor make any other disposition of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession or under their control at the time they receive the notice until the city clerk consents to a transfer or disposition, or until twenty (20) days elapse after the receipt of the notice. All persons so notified shall, within five (5) days after receipt of the notice, advise the city clerk of all of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession, under their control or owing by them. (c) Action for tax collection. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article, the city clerk may bring an action in the courts of this state, any other state or of the United States in the name of city to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. (d) Duty of successors or assignees of licensee to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any amount under sections 3-251—3-256 sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city clerk showing that he has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. (e) Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price valued in money. Within thirty (30) days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the city clerk shall 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 73/414 either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address, as it appears on the records of the city clerk, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of the successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever occurs later. (f) Refund of tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under sections 3-251—3-256, it may be offset as provided in section 3-254(c) or it may be refunded provided a verified claim in writing therefor, stating the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded, is filed with the city clerk within three (3) years from the date of payment. The claim shall be audited and shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk. If the claim is approved by the city clerk and the city council, the excess amount collected or paid may be refunded or may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person from whom it was collected or by whom paid, and the balance may be refunded to such person, his administrators or executors. (g) The city council or its designated committee may decline to issue a license under this article when any person having any ownership interest in or control over the land or building in which the establishment to be operated pursuant to the license will be located does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section for the licensee. (h) If a person in whose name a license under this article is issued is not a county resident, such person must appoint and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this article may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. If the licensee is not a natural person, it will be required to appoint and maintain a registered agent in the county if it does not have in the county any agent upon whom process can legally be served for such entity under the laws of the state. The licensee shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of such agent, with the city clerk. (i) An application for a license under this article may be denied where it appears to the city council or its designated committee that the applicant does not have adequate financial strength, adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended or is likely to be a surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license under this article. (j) The city council or its designated committee, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the establishment. If, in the city council's or the committee's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. (Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 74/414 (7) Charter reference— Authority to regulate, and to require vaccination, § 30. (7) Cross reference— Disposal of dead animals, §§ 9-117(4), 9-125(c). (7) State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-5, 16-12-4. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: Animal: Any member of the family "animalis." At large: Off of the property of the animal's owner, unless under control of the owner or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets or highways of the city. Attack dog: A dog which has been trained in any manner to attack persons or animals upon command. Cat: Any animal classified as "felis libyca domestica." Control: An animal shall be deemed to be under control when it is controlled by a leash or other physical attachment or is within the property limits of its owner or beside a competent person and obedient to such person's command or is in a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets or highways of the city or is in the rear of a pickup or open truck and controlled by a leash or other physical attachment. Dangerous dog: Any dog that, according to the records of animal control: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human without provocation on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989; or (2) Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. Dog: Any animal classified as "canis familars." Dog control officer: An individual selected under this Code or under provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c) to aid in the administration and enforcement of this chapter and applicable state law. Guard-security dog: A dog which has been trained or is used for guard and/or security purposes. Inoculation: The administration of antirabic vaccine, approved by the board of health of the county, administered by a licensed veterinarian or other person approved and authorized by such board of health to administer inoculations. Kennel, city: Three (3) or more dogs six (6) months or older. (See the zoning ordinance for more complete detail.) Kennel or pound, county: Any premises designated by the animal control department for the purpose of impounding and caring for dogs and other animals found at large in violation of this chapter. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 75/414 Livestock: Any animal of the equine, bovine, or swine class, including goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle, and other grazing animals. Owner: Any person as defined in section 1-2, specifically including but not limited to an individual, corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owner, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dog, dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or any other animal within the city. Potentially dangerous dog: Any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989. Proper enclosure: An enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children or other individuals and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. A symbol indicating a dangerous dog will be posted clearly (see section 4-42, Figure 1). Records of an appropriate authority: Records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county, or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state, or local court; or records of a dog control officer provided for in this chapter. Severe injury: Any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. Vicious animal: A savagely aggressive, or dangerous, animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings. State law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-3-2, 4-8-21. Sec. 4-2. - Violation; penalties. (a) Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with any requirement hereof shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a first offense, not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a second offense, and not less than four hundred dollars ($400.00) and not more than six hundred dollars ($600.00) for a third offense, or imprisoned in the county jail for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, and in addition shall pay the cost of such action. (b) If a person who has three (3) previous convictions for a violation of this chapter knowingly and wilfully fails to comply with any provision hereof, charges against such person shall be referred to the district attorney for prosecution. (Ord. No. 88, §§ 19, 30, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-3. - Redemption of impounded animals—Procedure; fees. Any animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be reclaimed, except as provided herein for dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs, by its owner by payment of a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the first impoundment, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the second impoundment, and thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the third impoundment, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for the fourth impoundment, and one hundred dollars 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 76/414 ($100.00) for each impoundment thereafter, plus a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day of impoundment. Any animal which is not reclaimed by its owner within five (5) days pursuant to section 4-4 may be adopted by payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). In the event that such reclaimed or adopted animal is required by law to be vaccinated or inoculated, such person reclaiming or adopting such animal shall reimburse the city for the cost of such vaccinations and inoculations. The animal control department shall cause such animals to be vaccinated or inoculated at the expense of the person reclaiming or adopting such animal. (Ord. No. 88, § 11, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-4. - Same—Disposition of unreclaimed animal. Any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter which is not reclaimed within ten (10) days by its owner may be disposed of in a recognized humane manner by the animal control department, or placed in the custody of some person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner and who shall agree to comply with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 88, § 12, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-5. - Liability of city and employees. (a) In the operation and enforcement of this chapter, the city assumes no liability or responsibility for the enforcement or nonenforcement of this chapter. By owning or maintaining such animals in the city, the owner or possessor of such animal consents to the operation of and enforcement of this chapter. By operation and enforcement of this chapter, the city makes no representation upon which members of the public may rely for their safety. (b) The city officers and employees, and other delegated persons of the animal control, shall not be liable for any injury to any animal picked up as a result of a violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 88, §§ 16, 29(G), 35, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-6. - Abandonment of animals. (a) No person shall release an animal on any property, public or private, with the intention of abandoning the animal. (b) No person shall intentionally abandon a dead animal on any private property belonging to another unless the person so doing shall have first obtained permission from the owner of the property on which the animal is being left. (c) No person shall abandon a dead animal on any public property or public right-of-way unless the place on which the animal is being left is an approved sanitary landfill or other facility designated by the city as a public facility for receiving trash or refuse. (Ord. No. 88, § 28, 9-11-89) State law reference— Abandonment of dead dogs, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-1.1, 4-8-2. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 77/414 Sec. 4-7. - Cruelty; neglect. (a) Prohibited: No person shall, by such person's act, omission or neglect, cause unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death to any living animal. This section does not apply to killing of animals raised for the purpose of providing food, nor does it apply to any person who hunts wild animals in compliance with the game and fish laws of this state. Killing or injuring an animal for humane purposes or in the furtherance of medical or scientific research is justifiable. (b) Permitted acts: No person shall perform a cruel act on any animal, nor shall any person harm, maim or kill any animal, or attempt to do so; except that a person may: (1) Defend such person's self or property or the person or property of another from injury or damage being caused by an animal; or (2) Kill any animal causing injury or damage to livestock or poultry. (c) Physical abuse: It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously kill, maim, disfigure, torture, beat with a stick, chain, club, or other object, mutilate, burn or scald with any substance, drive over or otherwise cruelly set upon any animal, except that reasonable force may be employed to drive off vicious or trespassing animals. (d) Failure to care for and maintain: It is unlawful for any person to fail, refuse, or neglect to provide any animal in such person's charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shade, care or shelter, or to carry any animal in or upon any vehicle in a cruel or inhumane manner. Any animal habitually kept outside shall be provided with a structurally sound, weatherproof enclosure, large enough to accommodate the animal. (e) Keeping diseased or crippled animal: It is unlawful for any person to have, keep, or harbor any animal which is infected with any dangerous disease or any incurable, painfully crippling condition. The animal control department may impound such diseased or painfully crippled animal, and all such animals impounded may be disposed of humanely as soon thereafter as conveniently possible. In the case of humane disposition of such animal, the animal control department shall not be required to give any notice. This section shall not be construed to include veterinary hospitals or animals under active veterinary care. (f) Authority of animal control department in case of animal neglect: Whenever the animal control board finds that any animal is or will be without proper care because of injury, illness, incarceration or other voluntary absence of the owner or person responsible for the care of such animal, or because of the failure, refusal or neglect of the owner or person responsible for the care of such animal to provide proper care, the animal control department may pick up such animal for protective care; and in the event of sickness or injury, the animal control department may take such action as called for to prevent undue pain and suffering, including immediate humane disposal of the animal. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 78/414 (Ord. No. 88, § 29, 9-11-89) State law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-5, 16-12-4. Sec. 4-8. - Vicious animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious animal upon the public property, streets, alleys or rights-of-way of the city, or any other public place therein, or on the premises of another, without permission, at any time, unless, in addition to the other requirements of this chapter, such animal shall be securely muzzled and controlled by a leash or other physical attachment not longer than six (6) feet to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal. (Ord. No. 88, § 15, 9-11-89) Cross reference— Dangerous dogs, § 4-40 et seq. Sec. 4-9. - Application of provisions to exotic animals and other animals. All sections of this chapter pertaining to vicious animals, dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs, shall apply to all exotic animals, all animals other than those specifically mentioned herein, and any animal with a known propensity to bite, and/or with a known vicious tendency. (Ord. No. 88, § 19, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-10. - Biting animals—Impoundment. Any animal which bites any person shall be impounded as provided for herein for a period of ten (10) days for observation, and upon release to the owner shall be inoculated and tagged as provided in this chapter. (Ord. No. 88, § 16, 9-11-89) State law reference— Notice of bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4. Sec. 4-11. - Same—Posting of premises. The owner of any animal which bites any person as a first offender shall post on the premises where such first offender is located a clearly visible sign warning "Beware of Dog," and/or "Beware of Animal." (Ord. No. 88, § 17, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-12. - Rabies inoculation; tag and collar required; identification. All dogs and cats located within the city shall be inoculated for rabies and shall wear a collar to which shall be attached a valid vaccination tag and an identification tag, label or impression showing the name and address of the owner of such dog or cat. In addition thereto, any other animal required by the laws of this state to be inoculated or vaccinated shall have attached a valid vaccination tag. (Ord. No. 88, § 9, 9-11-89) Secs. 4-13—4-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DOGS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 4-20. - Dog control officer—Designated; arrest powers. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 79/414 With the consent of the county animal control, the director of the animal control and the director's designees shall be designated as dog control officers as provided in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c) in cooperation with the city police department in carrying out the duties of the dog control officer. A person shall not be authorized to make arrests unless that person is a law enforcement officer having the powers of arrest. (Ord. No. 88, § 20, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-21. - Same—Interference therewith. No person shall hinder, molest, or interfere with any person authorized or empowered to perform any duty with reference to dogs under this article. (Ord. No. 88, § 13, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-22. - Dog census. The chief of police shall annually cause a canvass to be made of all dogs owned or harbored within the city, and shall report the results, including the names of all persons owning or harboring such animals, to the city clerk. (Ord. No. 88, § 14, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-23. - Dogs at large—Generally. Every dog within the city shall be either kept on a leash being held by the owner or kept within a fenced area or other area which confines such dog to a limited area. Any dog found roaming the streets shall be forthwith seized by the proper authority and the owner shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8. (Ord. No. 88, § 33, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-24. - Same—Female dogs in heat. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any female dog to allow such dog to run at large while in heat. (b) Any person violating this section shall be caused to pay a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) after trial and conviction in the municipal court. (Ord. No. 88, § 32, 9-11-89) State law reference— Permitting female dogs in heat to roam at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6. Sec. 4-25. - Registration of attack and guard-security dog; fees. (a) The owner of an attack dog and/or a guard-security dog which is either housed, leased, rented, or utilized in the city shall register such dog with the animal control officer as an attack and/or guard-security dog. (b) Upon registration the owner of an attack and/or guard-security dog shall pay, in addition to all other fees, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. No. 88, § 18, 9-11-89) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 80/414 Sec. 4-26. - Dog license—Required; application; evidence of inoculation required; issuance of tag. (a) Every person owning or harboring a dog within the city shall, on or before the fifteenth day of January in each year, apply to the city clerk for a license for each dog so owned or harbored, and at the time of application shall present and file with the city clerk a certificate signed by either: (1) a licensed veterinarian of the state showing that such dog has been inoculated against rabies within one (1) year, or (2) by some properly qualified person approved by the board of health. Whereupon, after the payment of the fee hereinafter set forth, the city clerk shall issue to such person a license, together with an official tag, which tag shall be fastened to the collar of the dog so licensed. In the event of a dog being acquired after the fifteenth day of January, a license shall be obtained as aforesaid within one (1) month after the date of acquiring the animal. (b) No person shall attach a license tag to any dog to which it is not issued or remove a license tag from the collar of any dog without the consent of its owner. (Ord. No. 88, §§ 2, 13, 9-11-89) Cross reference— Rabies inoculation, § 4-12. Sec. 4-27. - Same—Fees; expiration; not applicable to "licensed kennels"; lost, etc., tags. (a) Initial: The fee for obtaining the dog license required shall be two dollars ($2.00) for each dog. Such license shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of the year obtained. The license fee mentioned in this section shall not apply to dogs in a licensed kennel. (b) Replacement of lost, etc., tags: If any such tag required is lost or destroyed, the owner, on making affidavit of such loss before the city clerk and paying one dollar ($1.00), shall receive a new tag. The number of the lost tag shall be noted on the city clerk's register and a list of such lost numbers shall be reported to and kept by the chief of police. (Ord. No. 88, §§ 6, 7, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-28. - Same—Delinquent applications. For any application made thirty (30) days after the fifteenth day of January, the applicant shall be assessed a penalty of fifty (50) percent of the license fee, which amount shall be added and collected with the regular license fee. The aforesaid penalty is not applicable in the event the animal is acquired after the fifteenth day of January. In this event, the above stated penalty will be enforced at the expiration of thirty (30) days after the date of acquiring the animal. (Ord. No. 88, § 3, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-29. - Kennel license. The fee for obtaining a license known as a "kennel license" shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Such license shall only be issued to persons dealing in, boarding, or caring for dogs and shall cover all dogs in their custody, provided, that each dog in the care and custody of any such person having a kennel license shall have been vaccinated against rabies within one (1) year and shall bear an identification tag approved by the board of health, 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 81/414 showing that such dog has been properly inoculated against rabies. The word "kennel" shall apply to anyone selling or boarding dogs. (Ord. No. 88, § 8, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-30. - Transfer of licenses. (a) If there is a change in ownership of a dog or kennel during the license year, the new owner may have the current license transferred to such person's name upon payment of a transfer fee of fifty cents ($0.50) to the city clerk. (b) Licenses are not transferable from one (1) animal to another. (Ord. No. 88, §§ 4, 5, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-31. - Impoundment. (a) It shall be the duty of every police officer to seize and impound or cause to be seized and impounded, any dog at large within the city not bearing tags as provided in this chapter. (b) Furthermore, all animals found at large upon public places or upon the premises of another or upon the public streets, highways, alleys, and rights-of-way of the city, in violation of this chapter, shall be immediately impounded by the animal control department. The city employees, or any other persons or delegated persons of the animal control shall not be liable for any injury to any animal picked up under this section. (Ord. No. 88, § 10, 9-11-89) Cross reference— Redemption, § 4-3; disposition of unclaimed animal, § 4-4. Sec. 4-32. - Barking, etc., dogs. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to own or keep within the city any dog which, by barking, biting, howling, or in any other manner, disturbs the quiet of any person. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to cause, either by disturbance or by any other means, any dog to bite, bark, howl, or in any other manner disturb the quiet of any person. (c) Any person violating the above provisions of this section shall be caused to pay a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) after trial and conviction in the municipal court. (Ord. No. 88, § 31, 9-11-89) Secs. 4-33—4-39. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS OR POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOGS 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 82/414 Sec. 4-40. - Investigations; notice of classification as dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dogs. (a) Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within a dog control officer's jurisdiction from any law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this division. (b) When a dog control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog or reclassifies a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner in writing, as specified in section 4-41 herein, by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. (Ord. No. 88, § 21, 9-11-89) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23. Sec. 4-41. - Procedure for classification as dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; notice, hearing. (a) As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedure provided for in this section must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this division against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedure provided for in this section shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this division. (b) When a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification. (c) The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailing by certified mail to the owner's last-known address; (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (Ord. No. 88, § 22, 9-11-89) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23. Sec. 4-42. - Requirements for possessing dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs; registration, insurance, notice to dog control officer, enforcement. (a) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 83/414 It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within this city a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25. (b) Subject to the additional requirements of subsection (c) of this section for dangerous dogs, the dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of such dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer, or the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: (1) A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; and (2) The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property and containing a symbol designed to inform children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Such sign shall be in the shape of a diamond, similar to a standard highway warning sign, composed of eight-tenths (.08) gauge aluminum sheeting and measuring twelve (12) by twelve (12) inches. The circle will measure ten and three-quarter (10¾) inches in diameter. The figure of the person shall measure five (5) inches from the top of the figure's finger to the bottom of the figure's feet. The top of the dog's tail to the person's elbow shall measure six and three-quarter (6¾) inches. The word "DANGER" shall measure one and one-eighth (1⅛) inches by six (6) inches. The sign will utilize two (2) colors; standard yellow and black. The background of the sign will be in standard yellow. The circle, the figures of the person and dog, and the word "DANGER" will be in black. (See Figure 1) Figure 1 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 84/414 (c) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within fifteen (15) days after the date shown on the notice, has the right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog: (1) The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board; (2) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this division on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and (3) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the agency. (d) When the animal control board receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within thirty (30) days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 85/414 owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time, and place of hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and in addition thereto the board shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. (e) Within ten (10) days after the date of the hearing, the animal control board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. (f) The owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer immediately upon discovery if it is on the loose, unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (g) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the city shall register the dog as required in this section within thirty (30) days after becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from another jurisdiction to this city shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in this city within ten (10) days after becoming a resident. (h) Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. (i) A dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. The chief of police shall cooperate with dog control officers in enforcing the provisions of this division. (j) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25, the dog control officer shall charge an additional fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year for registration of dangerous dogs and a registration fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for registration of potentially dangerous dogs. Such fees shall be in addition to all other fees normally charged for the registration of dogs. Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, a dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this division. (Ord. No. 88, § 23, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-43. - Restrictions on permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dog to be outside of proper enclosure. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 86/414 (a) It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash not longer than six (6) feet and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration, but will prevent it from biting any person. (b) It is unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash no longer than six (6) feet and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (Ord. No. 88, § 24, 9-11-89) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-29. Sec. 4-44. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds, disposition. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the: (1) Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by O.C.G.A. § 2-4-23(c)(1), (2); (2) Dog is not validly registered as required by section 4-42(a); (3) Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 4-42(b)(1). (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is: (1) Not validly registered as required by section 4-42(a); (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 4-42(b)(1). (c) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 87/414 Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this division and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. The city or the animal control board shall not be liable for any injury to any animal picked up in violation of this division. In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within twenty (20) days after the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be disposed of in an expeditious and recognized humane manner by the animal control department. (d) The owner of the dog shall pay the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a confiscation fee, whether the owner shall claim the dog or not. (Ord. No. 88, § 25, 9-11-89) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-30. Sec. 4-45. - Violation; penalties. (a) The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 4-41 or section 4-42 or whose dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under subsection (a) of section 4-44 shall be incarcerated for a period of up to sixty (60) days. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be imposed for the first conviction, a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for the second conviction, and the owner shall be punished under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(b) for the third conviction. (b) The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 4-41 or section 4-42 or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under subsection (b) of section 4-44 shall be incarcerated for a period of up to sixty (60) days. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be imposed for the first conviction, a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be imposed for the second conviction, and a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be imposed for the third conviction. (c) If an owner who has a previous conviction for a violation of this division knowingly and wilfully fails to comply with the provisions of this division, charges against such owner shall be referred to the district attorney for prosecution under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(c) or (d) if the owner's dangerous dog attacks or bites a human being under circumstances constituting another violation of this division. (d) In addition to the penalties for violation under subsection (c) of this section, the dangerous dog involved shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by law enforcement officers or another person authorized by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health, thereafter, the dangerous dog shall be disposed of in an expeditious and recognized humane manner by the animal control department. (Ord. No. 88, § 26, 9-11-89) Sec. 4-46. - Exceptions. (a) 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 88/414 A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties or is a guard-security dog or attack dog which is being used for guard and/or security purposes shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this division. (b) A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this division if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a wilful trespass or other tort or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. (c) No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this division for injuries inflicted by such owner's dog to any human being while on such owner's property and within the enclosure as described in section 4-1, if such injured person was a trespasser upon the land. (Ord. No. 88, § 27, 9-11-89) Cross reference— Impoundment of biting animal, § 4-10.

(2) Standard Building Code, 1994 edition. (3) Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code, 1985 edition. (4) Standard Fire Prevention Code, 1994 edition. 5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances 89/414 (5) Standard Gas Code, 1994 edition.
